title: Prolly the best Microsoft has
text: Not normally a huge fan of Microsoft, but I must admit this professional suite really is fantastic. Our large healthcare system has recently gotten on board with not only Outlook, but also the rest of the suite which includes Teams, calendar, and many many other apps. The integration is really what makes the product work. So seamless and actually pretty intuitive, which is a new direction for Microsoft. Best of all, the entire suite (files on OneDrive, Teams, email, calendar, etc.) is avail as apps on the phone/tablet as well as your desktop, so you have connectivity and you’re always current and synced up no matter where you are. The phone apps in particular are surprisingly powerful, friendly and stable.

title: Audio Stopped Working!
text: My business is in the Music Industry so I receive a bunch of emails with audio files in them. This version of the app has taken awake the feature to listen to audio file. Your iPhone must be in ring mode in order to listen to the files if your phone is in vibrate mode it will not play the audio. Switching from vibrate to sound will start to wear out your iPhone switch. Most of the people I know have their phones on vibrate so that is a bad feature to take away. Also if you leave the app or lock your phone the audio stops playing which is another horrible idea. They should have not taken this feature away! Now we much export the audio to our OneDrive or our Apple Drive in order to listen to audio and continue answering messages. We get a bunch of versions for 1 song so it is a hassle to have to download and delete every version that is sent to us. Please bring these features back .

title: Average Mail App
text:
It’s a pretty good overall mail app, but not sure why it is rated so high. It has some seriously glaring issues, at least when linked to a Gmail account. Issues like:
1. It creates drafts that don’t go away after you send the email - so you look and think you haven’t replied because there’s an open draft. This is HORRIBLE if knowing whether you’ve replied is important to you. I’ve double-sent a few emails already. 
2. You can’t separate calendar integration. I’m running my calendar through a calendar app, so no reason for this to be fiddling with it. Creates redundancy and errors. 
3. Longer conversations are indented when reading back through the thread to the point you get a single character lines. Imagine trying to read a long email with one character per line. 

I still find it a better integration to Gmail than the native iOS Mail app, but only because Mail seems to not play nice with Gmail push notifications (as in I don’t get them). I’m not using Gmail (yet) because I was hoping to keep personal and work email notifications separate, BUT I may have to switch over. The draft problem is actually really bad for someone client-facing that doesn’t want to look like a chump not knowing when they’ve replied or not. 

Aesthetics are pleasing. Actually get your notifications on time. But some serious functional hitches.

title: It can be better!!!
text: As far as the app itself, it is ok. But there is much room for improvement. For example, when creating an email signature in Outlook (on a PC), company logo comes across just fine. However, when trying to use the same signature block and company logo from the iOS app, it is not consistent–the iOS app rejects the photo (jpeg, png etc.) and on the recipient end, all you see in place of your company logo is a white box with a red “x” saying the image cannot be displayed because it was removed…The Outlook application on the PC has an option to toggle HTML format to be on and I believe it this is what the iOS app needs so that email signatures (including company logos) are consistent between PC and iOS. Will Outlook PLEASE consider fixing this issue! Otherwise when emails are sent from an iOS device, the signatures are not consistent, making the email look LESS professional, which is NOT acceptable.

title: Few advantages, not competitive. For people who don’t know better.
text: Every year I try Outlook again and every year I delete it immediately because it remains inferior to other apps. Still can’t adjust messages preview to one or zero lines to show more messages on one screen. Still no 7 day or work week calendar in portrait mode or work week calendar in landscape mode. Search is still useless for me, cluttering up screen with no adjustable preview size, no idea what determines “top results” so I can’t trust that I see everything that I search for, meaning I have to scroll. Still no select for batch operations like delete or move. Still under-whelming bloatware that I should be paid to use. The only changes from release to versions are still trivial and cosmetic. Typical Microsoft garbage, no feature parity. Product management strategy just miserable. Back to my favorite mail and calendar apps that I willingly pay for instead of this free outlook.

title: Ever since iOS stopped allowing outlook mails to be configured using your iPhone settings
text: We have had no choice but to use this ap now if we want MSN email accounts  on our iPhones. At first it worked fine, I got emails when they were sent, but I noticed my email count number was different than the emails in my inbox. Eventually, this stopped occurring after changing absolutely nothing on my part. Now, in order to receive emails, I have to manually push to get them. If I forget to push I don’t get the emails for however many hours or days goes by between my manual pushes. I will try to uninstall and reinstall I guess, but it’s definitely got some bugs, I don’t think it’s my phone, I keep it pretty clean.

title: Great email app. One thing could use improvement
text:
Microsoft has really improved on this app for the iPhone. Less glitchy then the native app for exchange servers. Searching email is great. Love the calendar function, including the ability to respond to calendar invites on the email screen. Love how you can file emails pretty quickly, including the use of a search function for filing destinations. Love the ability to assign a swipe-right or -left as a hot key (I assigned swipe right to file emails). 

 One request would be for intuitive suggestions for filing destinations (my old black berry used to provide this and simply file is my current 3d party software solution for Outlook on my laptop). But even as is, it deserves five stars!

title: Almost caused me to lose my job
text:
I had a “twofer” horrible situation and the help team at Outlook responded but didn’t do anything to help my issue. I have two VERY important jobs; one is with the state within which I live where attorneys are constantly trying to get in touch (as I work with them) and the other is the medical field. I’m trying to change jobs there and long story short, I thought ALL of my email was sending....it was not.  It has really made me look foolish for roughly six or so days.  Unbeknown to me my “sent mail” was/is going straight to my draft folder. It’s still not sending. It doesn’t even bounce back so the user thinks their mail sent! The worst part is, I can’t prove to anyone I sent it because it’s just showing the time a draft was saved without a time stamp! 

 I’ve done everything...reset my email, upgrade the app everything and nothing works. I WISH I had stuck to my gmail account for anything important. Do NOT get Outlook...they’ve grown too fast for their own good.

title: The inconvenience outweighs benefits
text:
I like the functionality of the Outlook app for reading email. Unfortunately, when I first installed it, if I sent emails from other apps those emails were hung up because by default Outlook disconnected the standard apple email app from my outlook account. But I didn't know this until I started to wonder why people were not replying. Also, it disabled syncing for Contacts with the apple Contacts app. That means that the messenger app and phone app were not recognizing my contacts, so I didn't know who was calling me or messaging me.  That was very frustrating. Once I figured out what Outlook had done, I enabled the sync with the standard apple apps. 
Microsoft was a little presumptuous when they assumed I didn't need to sync with all these other apps that are at the very heart of using my iPhone. That was very frustrating. I was almost tempted to give up my paid Microsoft email account and go over to an Apple me account.

title: Outlook for business.
text: I specialize in Security and protection of assets for my clients. I utilize Outlook tirelessly for communication with clients and have never had an issue of lost, dropped communication. Some of the other platforms, in my opinion, do not perform as well as Outlook and eventually there are security breach issues, lost or unsent communications and.. well you get the picture. I like the system and it fits my needs. I do wish however, that it retained more of the one off or rare contact email addresses but it may be just me not going an extra step of adding or tagging them properly. And..maybe a better system for assigning “nicknames” for the post. No one likes to change their name or brand because it was “taken”.

title: Does the job; but would like to block spam
text:
The Outlook app does what it supposed to; however I would like to officially block unwanted spam. My junk folder gets 100s of emails a day and there are times when legit emails somehow get sent to my junk folder even though their email is definitely in my contacts. It gets annoying to go through the all the junk to make sure that legit emails did not get sent to the junk folder in error

The block feature is available on the desktop version, however since I’m on the phone the majority of the time, I would like to have the block function be available for the junk folder. If the junk folder is set up to delete all junk, then a block feature should be included in the app. 

Thank you!

title: Overall great app for business.
text:
Great email options for folders, delete , archive etc. 
Calendar is fantastic, much easier to create new events than iOS default calendar app and works outstandingly if you are already using outlook for your corporate email. You can see the pictures and org charts of all your coworkers. Main gripe is reachability on the bigger phones like my 12 pro max to reach the trash bin ( which for some reason is all the way up at the top right of the screen when in an email) is horrible. Due to the search magnifying glass being right in the bottom middle I hit that 3 out of 4 times when trying to use reachability to delete an email one handed. Has made me switch back to iOS mail multiple times. Extremely aggravating. Please fix this!

title: Needs one major improvement
text: I love outlook email and have been using it for years. The one thing that could improve safety is to be able to select an email through the app and report it as spam without having to open the email itself and be exposed to the pictures being downloaded and telling hackers that this is a valid email address. Gmail lets you report spam that way. The only way you can report spam through Outlook is to open the spam email itself, and I don’t want to have to block all images from downloading from any email that I get to avoid this, I just want to be able to report an email as spam through the app without opening it first. This is an option on the browser but I use the app way more.

title: Annoying junk notifications
text: This app is great in a lot of ways, but lately it has been sending me a notification for Every. Single. Junk. Email. I double-checked my notifications settings and made sure that they were set to only send me Focused Inbox notifications. I tried removing then re-downloading the app. I tried logging out then logging in again. I tried updating it. I checked the notification setting Again. And yet this app is still the one that sends me the most notifications throughout the day, and the vast majority of them are unwanted. The thing is, the app KNOWS that they are junk mail. When I open the app those emails are in the junk folder where they belong. I would turn off the notifications from Outlook entirely if this wasn’t an important app for work. I can’t afford to miss a real email, but all the junk ones are driving me batty!

title: Reading email is sooo 2020.  Let Cortana read it for you!
text: One of the best features in Outlook mobile is the ability to catch up on all unread emails in you inbox by having Cortana read them to you. Go for a walk, exercise, or commute and let Cortana read your emails and record your replies, archive, or flag for follow-up. She’ll even suggest replies based on context. My recommendations for improvement: Fix the Apple Watch version that does NOT display any meeting details. For example, if I want to call into a webinar via my Apple Watch I can’t, because the phone numbers are often embedded in the body of the appointment which the Watch App no longer displays (it used to last year 2020). Other than that, I’ve loving Outlook Mobile.

title: This is a great app
text: This is a great app.   Way better than gmail.  The things google does wrong, Microsoft does right.   There’s no built in browser.  It just opens things to my safari. Which is what I like.  There’s a dark mode. Also there’s a focused mailbox so it’s almost like Googles inbox program.  You can have it integrate your email into a single inbox. I got iCloud and gmail working.  What’s even better is that it seems to make gmail do push email.  I got tired of gmail and it’s lack of push on IOS.  And I hate it’s app.  So I am switching to Microsoft outlook Mail.  I thought I would try this and wasn’t expecting it to be great.  But Microsoft’s email app is fantastic.   This might be the best email app on iOS.  Give it a try.

title: Emails used to sync but not anymore
text: This is my second year using outlook for school and still not all of my emails I have in my inbox are syncing together. At the beginning of last school year, all of my emails synced together with my computer and the app but sometime in the beginning of the second semester that year was when syncing stopped. It’s like my inbox in the app is only letting me see my two recent emails and when I get a new one, the older one of the two emails “delete” but I know they are still there because all of my emails are in my inbox when I log into it on my computer and nothing is in my trash. Also, support is terrible because I tried contacting them and explained my issue in depth and said they couldn’t help me when it was an issue with the app and not the whole program. I tried deleting the app and reinstalling it and it didn’t work. If anyone knows what I’m talking about, I’ll know I’m not alone in this issue.

title: Ok but a couple issues
text: This app used to work great but I have 2 main gripes now. First it’s super frustrating that iOS won’t keep the app open in the background. Right now when you come back to the app everything is all closed up and you revert right back to the inbox. If you were in the middle of composing an email. Too bad. If you were in the middle of a keyword search and browsing the results, too bad. The other issue is when locating old emails (through search for instance) they are heavily deprecated... no images, no attachments, and no way to forward or download the original attachments and retain the info. This feature used to work great and about 6 months ago is when it broke. Fix these two issues and I would give 5 stars.

title: Outlook convenience
text: I have been using Outlook for quite a few years now and it has been wonderful because it’s very user-friendly. I love the calendar where I can actually schedule event and connected to my personal Gmail on whatever equipment I used such as my iPhone on my computer as I said is extremely user-friendly inside I’ve never had any problems with it it’s quick it’s easy and I love the notifications off and the fact that you could leave opportunities for learning how to use each tool that it it it allows us to use. I am very happy with this app Outlook it’s always been great for me to use and it’s Universal you could use it to the school work and just as personal tool.

title: Missing Voice Command (Siri) and Conference Call Automation’s
text:
I gave this 1-star rating because Microsoft is encouraging IT departments to isolate Microsoft Outlook from IOS.  This practice removes the ability to use awesome applications like Mobile Day with voice command to join your next call when traveling.  This implementation makes the Outlook App for IOS unsafe for business drivers.  It’s not always possible to pull over and if the call drops your back to square one again.  

Microsoft,  please stop this isolation practice until the Microsoft Outlook application for iOS has all the necessary functionality needed for business travelers.

Why does this matter?  

Voice Command Missing: The lack of safe features like voice command, Siri or google voice command integration.  In the past we used apps like Mobile Day to make joint next meeting fast and easy.

Conference Call Automation’s: This app lacks the ability to assemble a conference call number with the passcode for automated calling.  If the person originating the call doesn’t create a single click line then you have to manually enter the information.  This is not easy when traveling.

Voice Reminders:  the calendar should automatically join the next call or remind you of the next meeting.

Yes, this app has significant improvements but locking out the build in IOS capabilities is a horrible direction until the application meets the needs of all users.

title: Wish it was better but still pretty decent
text:
I love the fact that the email is in the same app as the calendar but I wish the app was better. It always falls short of what I want. But not in major ways.

I have multiple emails linked to it and wish I could cross save emails between the accounts (iphone’s app lets you do that).

Yesterday the app asked for the password to one of my email accounts. I ended up having to uninstall and reinstall the email account. Today it is asking for another password to a different account and this one won’t take. Even when I uninstalled and and tried to reinstall. (If this doesn’t get fixed, I will have to delete the app and use something else)

I hope Microsoft incorporates other calendar options to the calendar section so my iphone calendar can be added and this app can alert me to the birthdays I have saved in my contacts. I also wish the alert times were customizable and offered a second alert or a travel time alert.

It would also be nice if it had it’s own contact list to store contact information that I don’t necessarily want saved with my phone contacts.
(I don’t like to store contacts within my email accounts.)

Overall, I find it the best option for my needs and hope it will only get better in the future.

title: Best mail app ever!
text: I have been using outlook for quit some time. I have an apple phone and I don't even use the mail app It comes with I use Outlook I am able to put all my E-mail accounts into my outlook app I can access all my email in just this app also I was able to add another app that I use for my school for my assignments and they’re due dates onto outlooks calendar so I get reminders on when my assignments are due this is really the best email app I have ever used it’s easy to use all my contacts sync up to the direct tree when I write an email through my email accounts I can access each account separately or just do it all together I love Outlook I’ll never use another email app ever outlook is the best!

title: Mainly works but full of bugs
text: I need to use this email application for work. For the most part it works well despite not having a lot of the functionality of a regular email client. One issue is the when security pins are required the software glitches out on a regular basis requiring me to reset the application and re-enter my pin. Another really annoying issue is this app seems unable to properly display notifications! I do not know if it is iOS or Microsoft but I constantly have red bubbles for emails I have already seen and closed. Sometimes the notification bubble will disappear only to reappear moments later, and will not go away until I revisit the app and refresh again. This extends to new emails. I will have one new email and the notification bubble will display the number two, causing me to check multiple inboxes to make sure I’m not missing anything. Annoying on an hourly basis - please fix!!!

title: Mostly Works
text: The email functionality of Outlook on my iPhone works pretty well. I can send and receive emails that are properly synced with the iPhone, Outlook server and my pc desktop. The calendar functionality is less robust and there are sync issues that appear to be random - sometimes appointments sync and sometimes the do not. The only robust solution is to use the desktop to record the appointment. That usually results in a proper sync. But entering from the iPhone is hit or miss. And forget about the the iCloud calendar. That never syncs. I spent hours on the phone with support and trying their solutions without success. I finally gave up and don’t use the iCloud calendar. Instead I transfer any appointments that end up there to Outlook from my desktop.  Inconvenient but at least I don’t miss anything.

title: Great app, with one huge issue
text:
I really like the Outlook app for iOS. After years of using the standard Mail app, I decided to switch because the Mail app is horrible when using multiple different emails. Dare I say, the Outlook app is better in every way, except one.

The Outlook app doesn’t seem to store more than 30 days worth of emails locally on my phone. So if I needed to find an email from, say June 2017, I type it in the search bar and then I have to continue pressing the “Load more conversations” button ~60 times until the app finally syncs back far enough with the server to load the email. And then, once you close the app, it doesn’t save all of the emails you just loaded so now you have to start from the beginning the next time you search for an old email!!

From trial and error, it seems to pull old emails in 2-week chunks, so god have mercy on your soul if you have to go back 5+ years.

It boggles my mind why this is a thing. I’ve looked through every single setting in the app and on the desktop web but there’s no option to extend this limit. Why not simply do one massive sync where you pull everything and then save a local copy on my phone so I can actually find what I’m looking for without spending 30 mins pinging the server over and over again?! Both the Gmail app and the Mail app do this.

title: Don’t use unless you ads in your emails and not being able to see any emails at all
text: Overnight Microsoft outlook seems to have updated the system and now my emails do not display. I refresh the page and the emails are there for a second and they disappear. if I scroll down sometimes they are there for a lot longer and I can actually look at my emails, but the minute I scroll to the top of the page all the emails disappear again. do not download this app. Do not use Microsoft. I would go to Gmail since they do not actually mess with your emails like this. This is very important business information that I’m now not able to access and it’s costing me lots of money to not be able to access the information I need in my emails. The website is even worse. Nothing is there and I can’t stand losing clients in one darn day due to this change ( missing an important email cost me an expensive client today). Thanks jerks.

title: Feedback on Outlook 365 Email mobile and desktop.
text:
My main concern is how to manage email based on Focus and Other categories. As emails accrue it gets comply to stay on top of emails that are tied to subject message trails. Also the move messages feature versus mail to other folders is clunky to directly move a message to its intended folder. The top 10 recent folders pop up is effective and should also be in the move to other folder features

Final suggestion, Google mail has a feature where to move a message to a folder you can start to spell the folder and it quickly identifies the folders alpha spelling range. Usually you only have to type a few letters and you can move it faster. 

Thanks for considering my suggestions.

title: Microsoft excel and word problem
text: Have used app for a couple of years with no problems on iPhone or iPad. Email still works great, but now all of a sudden I can’t open excel or word attachments. I can e-mail docs out of Outlook app to gmail on phone or iPad and they open. It is an app issue. 18.0 update didn’t help. Nothing has helped. Reset, deleted etc. support could not help, “escalated” to higher support and communication almost non existent. Mostly sporadic questions and no answers. We are a huge organization and this cripples our mobility. Now as I try to publish this less than stellar review at a one star it won’t accept even the bazaar nic names! I’ll change to Five star and if your reading this you know they manipulate what reviews are posted. That’s crazy.

title: Too many rough edges, much worse than gmail app
text:
I run into quite a few aggravating issues in the outlook app. Using this app with Office 365, I am routinely get calendar reminders for events that have been cancelled (and they also show up in calendar, even if wait, and open the close the app to stimulate sync). I receive notifications, and then tap them, only to find outlook hasn’t downloaded the message, and can’t show it to me, but instead dumps me into inbox. And if I have a message open, and I switch back and forth between apps, eventually outlook loses its place and dumps me back into inbox (why? I was editing that, it has just here!). I also cannot view other people calendars from office 365 (as I can on outlook web and in Outlook on Win).

This app is plagued by issues like this that make it very unpleasant to use. It is death by a million paper cuts. I don’t love the gmail app, but gmail has the “reliability” issues down much much better than Outlook. Microsoft, you need to do better!

title: Major Bugs
text: I have been using the Outlook app on my iPhone for years (currently on iPhone 11). However recently, I started getting a notification to put my password in for Outlook. That pop-up repeats multiple times, and even after I put my password in, and it does not stop. This is a major bug, and is exceedingly annoying to say the least. I would like to see more functionality in the app itself, so it closer reflects the functions that people really need. I don’t use my laptop that frequently, so it would be nice to be able to do things like sweep or report junk on the app. These are things that people need every single day, and I think it is fair to say most people use their mobile devices as their primary way to access email. All the useless updates don’t seem to be making any changes to correct the major issues and flaws in this app.

title: Whole New World
text:
Emerging from the challenges of Asia where extending love to those who others might consider unlovable, I found myself embarking on a new path, utilizing Outlook to enrich my career. This phase of my life feels like an entirely new world, and learning to navigate Outlook is like mastering a new language. 

I’m incredibly grateful for the tools it provides in helping me efficiently organize and plan a schedule that has become increasingly full as God has blessed me with more opportunities. Thank you sincerely for your valuable service! 

I would appreciate it if there were links or tutorials available to learn about certain features like notes or sticky notes within Outlook, as I currently lack knowledge on using them. Once again, thank you, and let’s keep moving forward!

title: Worst Email Service Ever
text: I’ve had my Hotmail email account for over 10 years, and my Gmail account for even longer. Recently, Outlook decided to stop allowing me to send or receive emails because my storage was full. They didn’t warn me or have any pop ups in the Apple Mail app to tell me, so I thought I just didn’t have any new emails. A bit later I tried to order a time-sensitive car part and entered my Hotmail email address for contact as that is my priority inbox. Because Outlook decided to stop allowing my emails to send or received, I just found out after waiting for WEEKS that due to emails bouncing, the part order was cancelled. Now I have to go through the whole process again and wait another 2-3 weeks, all because Outlook can’t handle email storage like Google does. I even cleaned out all my files and emails and it’s still not updated the storage amount. Will be switching to Gmail permanently.

title: Developers—Please read for suggestion!!
text: Hi developers! I’ve been using Outlook for several years now because of college and I have had mostly good experiences with the app. Since my main devices are my iPhone and iPad Air, I didn’t experience the Mac version until I started working in an office with a Mac at my desk last semester. I love love love the new Outlook updates that recently came out for the Mac app, but something that REALLY irks me still is that while I can schedule send my emails from my Mac, I cannot do that from either my iPad or my iPhone. It’s very inconvenient when I need to schedule emails on the go out of office. PLEASE consider making this a possibility on iPhones and iPads! If Gmail can do it, you can too!! Pretty please! It would make our lives so much easier.

title: Can’t depend on this for any serious work
text: For approximately 90% of my emailing work which consists of a attaching a few PDFs and formatting messages, the app is fine to use. Managing multiple threads, labeling emails, and getting reminders are very well done on this app. However the app acts up when I most need it. For example, if I’m trying to attach multiple files that are not necessarily viewable on the iPad (e.g. CAD files), outlook requires me to select one file at a time and after 3 or so files, the app freezes. Basically, it tells me that some helper application has stoped responding and at that point the entire application slows down and I have to abandon creating the mail. It seems the app has issues with efficiently selecting multiple files for attachment, keeping those files attached, and sending the message with the files.

title: Best Mail App for O365
text:
I do think this is the best Mail App for O365. The features line up with the capabilities of the desktop and get better and better.  The only issues I have are:

1. The calendar needs a better month view. It’s just trying to show too much when you first hit it. Would be nice to get a clean month where you could click right to a day for details. Just kinda typical Microsoft clutter of the paste when whoever is driving the new UI really has a focus on better simplicity. I think this is a miss.

2. I still can’t believe after all these years now you can’t set a color for the left mailbox icons. It’s so basic and so necessary.

3. New feature are very “Microsofty” and should allow some customization… What if I don’t use MS Teams and don’t want to? Let me turn it off. What if I don’t want to use Cortana or Book a Workplace? Let me change the buttons.  I’m not going to use them no matter how in my face they are and if anything it’s going to give me a negative connotation of them. And I’m speaking for more people than just myself. It’s user feedback from our install bases.  The latest update highlights this.

Otherwise it keeps getting better.

title: Promising but Needs Improvement
text:
The app stops running in the background seconds after switching to other apps. Sometimes I have to switch back and forth between outlook and other apps. When switching back to outlook I see the splash screen again and than returned to the inbox. The email I was referencing has to be found again and reopened. 

Also, classic email behavior is to forward or reply only to selected text, or the entire message if no text is selected. I make use of this often in Apple Mail app and Outlook Mac. For some reason the iOS version doesn’t do this which is disappointing. 

Navigating folder structures is awkward if you have outlook syncing with multiple email accounts. One must first pick the account inbox first and then tap again to see account sub-folders.

title: Does a good job on most things
text: The Outlook app has come a long way and does a good job with email and calendars. A few things would make it great. The ability to drag an existing meeting to change it is the first one. Instead it creates a new meeting. You have to open meeting to change it. If it remembered what folder you put mail in like the mail app that's a nice second time saver. A great feature would be to be able to type in a folder you want to go to vs scrolling so that would be three. Their search is powerful but not as much as the Mac app where you can filter by who you sent to/from, what's in the subject, body, etc. I also have a fourth which would be to have Tasks available. Still does a pretty good job. But if it had the others, I'd give it a 5 and would pay for it.

title: I'd give this app negative stars if I could
text:
Just missed days of emails. When refreshing the inbox it gives ABSOLUTELY NO INDICATION IF IT FAILS TO CONNECT TO THE SERVER. A complete inability to receive messages becomes "no new mail." ARE YOU KIDDING ME? My organization required a password reset, so I guess Outlook couldn't authenticate. You'd think that would warrant some kind of prompt to the user to re-enter a password. This comes after YEARS of being forced to use this half-baked product. Just when it seems like it's working fine, they introduce a bunch of new bugs. Do they realize that organizations rely on this app in paid enterprise settings? How is this acceptable? The people in charge of steering this product should find new jobs. They're awful at this.

Update Feb 2023: New version is really cool. They left in all the bugs, and now it also nags you to install the Edge browser when you click outgoing links. It's a bold new direction in anti-consumer practices.

title: Only email app that can handle the deluge!
text: I get a metric sh!7-ton of email. (I average well over 1200/day.) I have tried literally every email app that exists on iOS, but Outlook is the only one that can handle my email needs gracefully.  When there is a new bug or issue with an update, I tend to be one of the first to find it because of my email volume.  Fortunately, the support is outstanding.  They are super responsive in-app, and they follow up until the issue is fixed.  I own a few software companies and invest as a VC.  Which is why I get so many emails. So I am familiar with developer teams.  The Outlook team are amazing, and I only wish others would rise to their standards. And this is coming from someone that spent most of my career hating on Microsoft.

title: I don’t understand how this app is so highly rated.
text: Is this app fantastic? Yes, with one caveat, it’s only fantastic when it works properly. I’ve had multiple issues such as dropped contact lists, the inability to send or receive emails, (over cellular data or WiFi, both of which have caused issues) and a few other bugs such as an inability to forward messages and the app being unable to find my co-workers via email even when typed in manually. I know this app is a god send for businesses on the go, but just because it’s almost necessary in today’s world doesn’t give it a pass to have as many bugs as it does. I would MUCH prefer to switch to a google based platform, as they have almost perfected integration of all of their services into one single google account with very few hiccups. I would love for Microsoft to be able to do the same.

title: Spam blocker doesn’t work
text:
I’ve use Microsoft for my emails since my first Hotmail account in the early 90s. Just in recent years spam email has gotten out of control. I’ve tried putting email addresses on my blocked contact list both in app and online. In app nothing even shows up on the list. Online marked senders appear on the blocked list but emails from them still come to my inbox. 

They did a study years back that showed the button for crossing at road intersections wasn’t actually connected to anything. It was just supposed to make people feel like they had some control. I think Microsoft spam email blocker is the same thing. Doesn’t really attempt to filter anything. Just make it feel like you’re doing something. 

I don’t know if their is an email client out there that has better security, but I will be looking for it.

title: Nice but ...
text:
First, I really like the look of the new Outlook.  I love Apple and have a home full of devices.  I tell everyone that I’m hypocritical as I load windows on my Mac first thing - which includes office.  

Rarely will you catch me writing a review but after frustratingly trying to get my ‘group’ from being greyed out — I just went back to the old version of outlook.  Problem solved.  I use groups for emails and I can’t even see my old groups in contacts.  I turn off the ‘new outlook’ and there they are.  Likely something very easy but being retired I’m not with my dedicated IT department, which is what my google of Microsoft online support suggests.

Perhaps there is some reason they don’t automatically make this available.  Maybe I’ll come back here and read up on it - likely won’t.  The new outlook looks great.  I agree with most of the reviews — both good and bad.  Microsoft with the switch to 365 has really been confusing to me as I don’t keep up with the tech side.  My email inbox of Microsoft 365 Message Center with the new features are usually deleted and perhaps I should give them more time, but that is precious commodity for me at this time.

I love Office and usually first to download updates and upgrades, maybe I just solved my own problem ...

Mark

title: Missing easy features, but now my primary mail client
text:
Most recent annoyance is that it regularly prompts me to re-login to my AAD account. This is new. Nothing has changed on the admin side. Annoying as I miss incoming email from displaying until it prompts to re-login, and then it works for a while. 

Day-to-day, it is a great product and reliable compared to Apple Mail for showing new incoming mail from Office 365 and handling calendar requests.

It is missing the ability to eliminate profile photos on the agenda view, as it makes it too busy looking (so not useful with so many and so small). It doesn’t show the my profile photo of each account when using multiple 365 mailboxes (for me, it shows the same letter twice with two different background colors I don’t get to choose). Even better would be allowing an image (that I choose) to represent. 

 It doesn’t support moving non-shared appointments to another account like the iOS calendar app. So, I need Apple Calendar when I mistakenly select the wrong calendar (to avoid deleting and recreating an appointment with all the details). Ugh!

title: Best email I’ve used
text: I love Outlook for its organization. It is so easy to create folders to store old messages I may need later. I also love that the messages stay connected. For instance, if I communicate with someone on several different days (replying to each other’s emails) it creates a thread of those replies rather than separating them into new emails - this way I can refer back to the old messages without having to search for them. I am very happy with outlook. I also love the calendar feature because outlook emails me my agenda for the day and allows me to keep multiple calendars. I have used outlook for four years through my college and when I left I decided to make another account. Many thanks to outlook for keeping my life sane!

title: Unusable, unintuitive, and unsecure
text: There's no way to delete Birthdays on the Calendar on mobile. Even if you delete the contacts they're still there. Delete address book and the contacts still show up in the Calendar, making this app a security risk if you have other people checking your phone and you have private contacts. Another thing is: if you delete all of your recently emailed contacts, new ones still show up (such as old obsolete emails you made and don't care about anymore) and also sometimes email addresses will all appear as deleted suddenly. This happens when you're deleting on one email address and the AI predicts that you're deleting all the addresses, it will show no contacts for the other letters on the other email addresses even though they're still there secretly. A petty issue you won't find on Apple Mail (but you will find similar issues to Outlook on Gmail).

title: Stopped fetching mail
text: I don’t know whether it’s a problem with my mail server or with certain email clients, but it will happen periodically that a given email client will simply stop fetching new mail from the server; I’ll launch the email client and the most recent emails I’ll see are from last week, while a different email client shows all my mail, up to the minute. And that’s just happened with Outlook. I was enjoying Outlook; it has a very clean, streamlined and professional presentation that appeals to me and I’ve found it very easy to use for the month or so that I’ve been using it. But if it’s going to randomly stop getting my new email, it is unfortunately useless to me. So I guess I’m going to head back to Spark for the time being and keep looking for an email client that I both like and can rely on. Outlook is the former but unfortunately not the latter.

title: Why is “reply all” the default...
text:
Literally so over getting countless extra emails from people who didn’t change it to “reply” instead of “reply all.” Why is reply all the default? It literally makes zero sense? If someone accidentally sends a message to one person instead of a whole group, it’s super easy to fix! They just have to forward it to the whole group. But if someone accidentally replies all when they should have just replied to the original sender, then everyone in the group gets yet another notification and has to click the message to make it go away. It also risks people sending something that wasn’t supposed to go to the whole group, like confidential information. When you work in a big school with a lot of staff, you get a ton of these bonus emails on top of the countless advertisement emails I already get that can’t be unsubscribed from.

So yeah, one star literally just because you make reply all the default. Annoying.

title: Does the job
text: Outlook for iPad is a competent Outlook implementation. It does the job it is meant to do and I have yet to have a problem with it. If only my marriage was so simple. My wife used to tell me how much she enjoyed when I would send her emails. Nowadays, she won’t even send me read receipts. She removed my IMAP configuration from the family computer and I can’t figure out how to put it back. I’m looking into POP3, but I can’t seem to figure that out either. I feel I may be lost without her. Outlook has been very supportive of me throughout this period. If we eventually divorce, I will be warmed by the kind blue glow of the Outlook application for iPad. That makes me feel like everything is going to be okay somehow.

title: The Convenience of Outlook
text: Been using Outlook for my emails for years, and I love the onvenience of being able to do so many things without the hassl e of logging in to some website, and learning how to navigate. My emails ae right there, easy to see with multiple colunms, right click replies, and drag and drop to repsecrtive folders. Easy to navigate, and filter out spam, and clearing deleted and junk emails. I can use it accross different devices and make changes in one device while affecting other without duplication. Microsoft engineers realy put a lot of thought into this app, and it functions well. THe united state post office could learn a lot about sending and receiving snailmail from Microsoft.

title: Sweep function is woefully limited
text:
The OLD sweep function allowed users to list sender addresses and instruct the system to keep emails from those senders for a specific number of days in the Inbox (to allow me, the user, to read and respond to them in my own time), then to move those emails automatically to a specific folder after the specified number of days I chose expire. 

NOW, the NEW sweep function allows the user to list sender addresses but ONLY for the purpose of DELETING those emails after a specified number of days!

What’s the point??? I don’t want emails from important senders to be deleted! I want them to go to a specific folder I’ve set up for a particular sender or matter!!

The existing function that allows the user to immediately direct new emails from a particular sender to a designated folder is simply an invitation for users like me to miss those emails altogether!! Being a busy human, sometimes I’m on the run, and sometimes I simply forget to check a bunch of individual folders for new (and sometimes very important messages)!

WHAT’S UP, OUTLOOK/MICROSOFT??? HOW DIFFICULT WOULD IT BE TO REVIVE THE OLD SWEEP FUNCTION??? 

You could still allow users who wish to delete emails from designated senders to do so by directing the emails from such senders to go to the Deleted folder after a certain number of days. 

COME ON!!!
